name: Planktonic Green Algae
scientific name: Scenedesmus, Pediastrum, Oocystis, Cosmarium, Staurastrum, others

Identifying Characteristics: Grass-green colored water looks murky (like green paint); individual algae are rarely visible

Color is caused by proliferation of microscopic free-floating (planktonic) plants, suspended in the top few feet of water of a pond or lake where light is bright enough for algae to produce food by photosynthesis
Under a microscope green algae takes many forms.  Some species are egg-shaped, some filamentous; others resemble barrels, snowflakes, bugs and more!
Biology: Reproduction is asexual, by vegetative cell division
Life cycles may include both single cell stage (some propelled by flagella) and multicellular stages consisting of cells being joined into thread-like filaments or geometric shapes
Numerous green algae species are naturally occurring in most Maine lakes, and are vital components of lake ecosystems
